title: .htaccess blacklisted by default with no explanation
body:
i searched both this issue queue and the docs site. the only topic on the forums that might apply is in a language i don't know. 

i could not find a solid explanation for why .htaccess files are blacklisted by default.

i can see .htaccess files being a security risk. but there are ways to make them just not work, and thus not be a security risk.

the problem is that many developers use the sync capabilities of dropbox to speed up their development work. switching between a desktop and laptop is a lot easier if you have all your dev work right there. for web developers, .htaccess files are a must have. my coworker is one of those who use dropbox that way. and one of the reasons i want to use owncloud is to do the same thing.

so, why are .htaccess files blacklisted by default? 

can we get a page on the docs site with that answer? as well as information on how to make .htaccess files not dangerous for those who are willing to put the effort out/take the risk? (like moving owncloud's directives into the vhost, and then disabling .htaccess with ```allowoverride none``, or changing what the .htaccess files are named with ```accessfilename```.)
